title: Oasis: The First AI-Generated Open-World Game
description: In this episode, we dive into Oasis, a revolutionary open-world game entirely generated by AI, and explore what it means for the future of gaming and technology.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we’re taking a deep dive into something truly groundbreaking—a video game called Oasis. And let me tell you, it’s not just any video game. This one is completely generated by artificial intelligence. No traditional game engines, no manual development of each game element. Everything in Oasis, from the world you explore to the rules you interact with, is created in real time by an AI model.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, you might be wondering, how does this even work? Oasis was developed by the team at Decart and Etched. It’s based on an architecture involving Transformers—yes, those same Transformers that have been making waves in natural language processing and image generation. Specifically, Oasis uses a combination of a spatial autoencoder and a latent diffusion backbone. Think of these as two parts of the brain that let the game understand and generate complex environments and interactions in real time.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The exciting thing here is that Oasis doesn’t just generate static worlds; it’s actually interactive. The game takes in user inputs, like moving, jumping, or picking up items, and generates the gameplay on the fly. The physics, the lighting, even the animals you meet—all of it is generated live. And because there is no game engine, this means there are essentially no predefined limits to what Oasis can create.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The performance, frankly, is nothing short of astonishing. The model runs at 20 frames per second, which is far beyond what other AI-driven video generation models have managed so far. Models like Sora or Mochi-1 can take up to 10-20 seconds just to generate a single second of video. Imagine trying to play a game like that! But Oasis, thanks to some impressive optimization using Decart’s inference engine, runs smoothly—enabling players to actually interact with the environment in real time, just as you would in a regular video game.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And the team behind Oasis isn’t stopping here. They’re working towards even higher performance by optimizing the model for specialized hardware—specifically, Etched's Transformer ASIC called Sohu. They believe that with this new hardware, Oasis could scale to massive models in 4K resolution, and that’s something that could redefine not only gaming but also how we think about creating any kind of interactive media.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Imagine a future where video games, movies, or even educational simulations are generated entirely by AI, adapting to your preferences, your choices, and even your mood in real time. And Oasis might just be the first step towards that kind of future.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But, like any experimental technology, Oasis does have its challenges. For one, the game sometimes struggles with maintaining perfect consistency over long stretches. For example, distant objects might appear fuzzy, or it may have difficulty with precise inventory control. These are typical growing pains for any AI model, and the Oasis team is confident they can solve these issues through larger datasets and better model scaling.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And it's important to point out, this isn’t just about playing a game. This is about transforming what it means to create digital experiences. Instead of a game being meticulously designed by a team of developers over years, what if it could just be described and then brought to life by an AI? This opens up opportunities for anyone with an idea to create their own world, their own story—without needing a big studio or budget.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: If you’re interested in seeing Oasis for yourself, the team has released the code, the weights of a 500 million parameter model, and even a live playable demo that you can try out. I highly recommend checking it out if you're curious about the future of AI and gaming. You can find all of this on their official page, linked in the episode description.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: This kind of project really makes me wonder: what will be the limits of AI creativity? Today it’s games, tomorrow it could be entire immersive worlds that are created based solely on your imagination. We’re definitely standing at the brink of something revolutionary here.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That’s it for today’s episode of 'Life is Artificial.' I hope you enjoyed learning about Oasis and the incredible future it promises. If you have questions or want to discuss more about how AI is changing our world, feel free to reach out. And as always, stay curious.
